data.title: Shashank R. Chakerwarti
data.meta_description: Youngest out of the eight children born to a farmer father, Michael John Collins, and mother, Mary Anne O'Brien on October 16, 1890, grew up to be a revolutionary Irish leader, founder of the Irish Free State and who dedicate a majority of his work to secure independence from the British Empire.
data.text:
Introduction:

Michael Collins is a pivotal figure in Irish history, renowned for his relentless dedication to securing Ireland's independence from the British Empire. This biography delves into the life of this remarkable leader, from his humble beginnings to his pivotal role in the Irish struggle for freedom.

​

Early Life and Education:

Born on October 16, 1890, as the youngest of eight children to farmer parents, Michael Collins grew up in the remote but beautiful southwest of Ireland. His education in local primary schools, particularly at Lisavair National School, laid the foundation for his future as a revolutionary leader. It was here that he was inspired by his teacher, Denis Lyons, and introduced to the Irish Republican Brotherhood (IRB), igniting the spark of Irish pride and independence in him.

​

Years in London:

In 1906, Collins ventured to London, England, to work as a postal clerk in the civil service. During his ten years in London, he actively participated in Irish organizations such as the Gaelic League and Sinn Fein, under the influence of Irish nationalist Arthur Griffith. His membership in the IRB, along with his role as the IRB treasurer for the South of England, marked his growing involvement in the fight for Irish independence.

​

Involvement in the Easter Rising:

Collins returned to Ireland in 1916 to take part in the Easter Rising, a significant rebellion against British rule. Following the suppression of the uprising, he, like many other rebels, was interned in North Wales. It was upon his release in December 1916 that he rose to prominence within the revolutionary movement in Dublin.

​

Revolutionary Activities:

With the victory in the 1918 general election, revolutionaries established Dail Eireann, Ireland's own parliament, and declared the Irish Republic. This marked the beginning of a fierce struggle against British rule, with the Irish Republican Army (IRA) employing guerrilla warfare tactics. Michael Collins played a central role as the director of intelligence for the IRA, dismantling British intelligence networks and securing funding as the minister of finance for the Republican government.

​

Diplomacy and the Treaty:

After the truce of July 1921, Collins reluctantly participated in peace talks led by Arthur Griffith. These negotiations resulted in the Anglo-Irish Treaty, which granted Ireland Dominion status within the British Commonwealth. However, the treaty divided the Republican movement, leading to a bitter dispute between those who accepted it, led by Collins, and those who rejected it, including Eamon de Valera.

​

Civil War and Tragic End:

The acceptance of the treaty led to the outbreak of the Irish Civil War in 1922. Collins and Griffith worked tirelessly to enforce the treaty, but they faced opposition from armed Republicans who saw it as a betrayal. In June 1922, Collins resorted to force against the opposition, sparking a civil war that ended in May 1923. Tragically, he did not live to see its conclusion, as he was ambushed and killed in West Cork on August 22, 1922, just ten days after the death of Arthur Griffith.

​

Legacy and Impact:

Michael Collins' legacy endures as a revolutionary leader known for his realism, efficiency, vision, and humanity. While the treaty did not immediately end the argument, it paved the way for Ireland to eventually achieve full political freedom.

​

Conclusion:

The life of Michael Collins is a testament to the unwavering spirit of those who fought for Ireland's independence. His journey from a remote Irish village to the heart of the struggle against British rule showcases the indomitable spirit of a man who left an indelible mark on Irish history.

​
